<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Bali skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Bali</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:EngvarB&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:EngvarB (page does not exist)">Template:EngvarB</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>Bali</b> is an island and the smallest province of <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, and includes a few smaller neighbouring islands, notably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Penida&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Penida (page does not exist)">Nusa Penida</a>. It is located at the westernmost end of the <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Sunda_Islands" title="Lesser Sunda Islands">Lesser Sunda Islands</a>, between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Java_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Java (island) (page does not exist)">Java</a> to the west and <a href="/wiki/Lombok" title="Lombok">Lombok</a> to the east, and has its capital of <a href="/wiki/Denpasar" title="Denpasar">Denpasar</a> at the southern part of the island.
</p><p>With a population of 3,890,757 in the 2010 census,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> and currently 4.22 million,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> the island is home to most of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Indonesia's Hindu minority</a>. According to the 2010 Census, 84.5% of Bali's population adhered to <a href="/wiki/Balinese_Hinduism" title="Balinese Hinduism">Balinese Hinduism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-census2010_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2010-3">[3]</a></sup> 12% to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Islam</a>, while most of the remainder followed <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>. Bali is also the largest tourist destination in the country and is renowned for its highly developed arts, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_dance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese dance (page does not exist)">traditional and modern dance</a>, sculpture, painting, leather, <a href="/wiki/Metalworking" title="Metalworking">metalworking</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Balinese_music" title="Balinese music" class="mw-redirect">music</a>. A tourist haven for decades, the province has seen a further surge in tourist numbers in recent years.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Bali was inhabited around 2000 BC by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austronesian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austronesian people (page does not exist)">Austronesian people</a> who migrated originally from Southeast Asia and Oceania through <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hinzler_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hinzler-5">[5]</a></sup> Culturally and linguistically, the Balinese are thus closely related to the people of the Indonesian archipelago, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Oceania.<sup id="cite_ref-Hinzler_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hinzler-5">[5]</a></sup> Stone tools dating from this time have been found near the village of Cekik in the island's west.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lonely_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lonely-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>In ancient Bali, nine Hindu sects existed, namely Pasupata, Bhairawa, Siwa Shidanta, Waisnawa, Bodha, Brahma, Resi, Sora and Ganapatya. Each sect revered a specific deity as its personal Godhead.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Balinese culture was strongly influenced by Indian, Chinese, and particularly <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> culture, beginning around the 1st century AD. The name <i>Bali dwipa</i> ("Bali island") has been discovered from various inscriptions, including the Blanjong pillar inscription written by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sri_Kesari_Warmadewa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sri Kesari Warmadewa (page does not exist)">Sri Kesari Warmadewa</a> in 914 AD and mentioning "Walidwipa". It was during this time that the complex irrigation system <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Subak_(irrigation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subak (irrigation) (page does not exist)">subak</a></i> was developed to grow rice. Some religious and cultural traditions still in existence today can be traced back to this period. The Hindu <a href="/w/index.php?title=Majapahit_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Majapahit Empire (page does not exist)">Majapahit Empire</a> (1293–1520 AD) on eastern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Java_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Java (island) (page does not exist)">Java</a> founded a Balinese colony in 1343. When the empire declined, there was an exodus of intellectuals, artists, priests, and musicians from Java to Bali in the 15th century.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Balinese_sculpture_with_umbrella.JPG" title="File:Balinese sculpture with umbrella.JPG">File:Balinese sculpture with umbrella.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">At religious festivals on Bali the sculptures get dressed up and umbrellas are placed by the temples.</div></div></div>
<p>The first <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_ethnic_groups&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European ethnic groups (page does not exist)">European</a> contact with Bali is thought to have been made in 1585 when a Portuguese ship foundered off the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bukit_Peninsula&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bukit Peninsula (page does not exist)">Bukit Peninsula</a> and left a few Portuguese in the service of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dewa_Agung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dewa Agung (page does not exist)">Dewa Agung</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> In 1597 the Dutch explorer <a href="/wiki/Cornelis_de_Houtman" title="Cornelis de Houtman">Cornelis de Houtman</a> arrived at Bali and, with the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> in 1602, the stage was set for colonial control two and a half centuries later when Dutch control expanded across the Indonesian archipelago throughout the second half of the 19th century (see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_East_Indies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch East Indies (page does not exist)">Dutch East Indies</a>). Dutch political and economic control over Bali began in the 1840s on the island's north coast, when the Dutch pitted various distrustful Balinese realms against each other.<sup id="cite_ref-ctpqur_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ctpqur-10">[10]</a></sup> In the late 1890s, struggles between Balinese kingdoms in the island's south were exploited by the Dutch to increase their control.
</p><p>In June 1860 the famous English naturalist <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace" title="Alfred Russel Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a> travelled to Bali from Singapore landing at Bileling on the northcoast of the island. Wallace's trip to Bali was instrumental in helping him devise his <a href="/wiki/Wallace_Line" title="Wallace Line">Wallace Line</a> theory. The Wallace Line is a faunal boundary that run through the strait between Bali and Lombok, which, though a short distance, is a boundary between species of Asiatic origin in the east and a mixture of Australian and Asian species to the west. In his travel memoir <a href="/w/index.php?title=%27%27The_Malay_Archipelago%27%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="''The Malay Archipelago'' (page does not exist)">''The Malay Archipelago''</a> Wallace writes of his experience in Bali:
</p>
<blockquote>I was both astonished and delighted; for as my visit to Java was some years later, I had never beheld so beautiful and well-cultivated a district out of Europe. A slightly undulating plain extends from the seacoast about ten or twelve miles inland, where it is bounded by a fine range of wooded and cultivated hills. Houses and villages, marked out by dense clumps of coconut palms, tamarind and other fruit trees, are dotted about in every direction; while between them extend luxurious rice-grounds, watered by an elaborate system of irrigation that would be the pride of the best cultivated parts of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> </blockquote>
<p>The Dutch mounted large naval and ground <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_intervention_in_Bali_(1906)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch intervention in Bali (1906) (page does not exist)">assaults at the Sanur region</a> in 1906 and were met by the thousands of members of the royal family and their followers who fought against the superior Dutch force in a suicidal <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Puputan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puputan (page does not exist)">puputan</a></i> defensive assault rather than face the humiliation of surrender.<sup id="cite_ref-ctpqur_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ctpqur-10">[10]</a></sup> Despite Dutch demands for surrender, an estimated 200 Balinese marched to their death against the invaders.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_intervention_in_Bali_(1908)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch intervention in Bali (1908) (page does not exist)">Dutch intervention in Bali</a>, a similar massacre occurred in the face of a Dutch assault in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Klungkung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Klungkung (page does not exist)">Klungkung</a>. Afterwards the Dutch governors were able to exercise administrative control over the island, but local control over religion and culture generally remained intact. Dutch rule over Bali came later and was never as well established as in other parts of Indonesia such as Java and <a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Maluku</a>.
</p><p>In the 1930s, anthropologists <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Mead" title="Margaret Mead">Margaret Mead</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Bateson" title="Gregory Bateson">Gregory Bateson</a>, and artists <a href="/w/index.php?title=Miguel_Covarrubias&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Miguel Covarrubias (page does not exist)">Miguel Covarrubias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Walter_Spies" title="Walter Spies">Walter Spies</a>, and musicologist <a href="/wiki/Colin_McPhee" title="Colin McPhee">Colin McPhee</a> created a western image of Bali as "an enchanted land of <a href="/wiki/Aesthetics" title="Aesthetics">aesthetes</a> at peace with themselves and nature", and western tourism first developed on the island.<sup id="cite_ref-Friend_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Friend-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Balinese_dancers.jpg" title="File:Balinese dancers.jpg">File:Balinese dancers.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_dance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese dance (page does not exist)">Balinese dancers</a> show for tourists, in <a href="/wiki/Ubud" title="Ubud">Ubud</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Imperial_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Imperial Japan (page does not exist)">Imperial Japan</a> occupied Bali during World War II. Bali Island was not originally a target in their Netherlands East Indies Campaign, but as the airfields on <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a> were inoperative due to heavy rains the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army" title="Imperial Japanese Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a> decided to occupy Bali, which did not suffer from comparable weather. The island had no regular <a href="/wiki/Royal_Netherlands_East_Indies_Army" title="Royal Netherlands East Indies Army">Royal Netherlands East Indies Army</a> (KNIL) troops. There was only a Native Auxiliary Corps <i>Prajoda</i> (Korps Prajoda) consisting of about 600 native soldiers and several Dutch KNIL officers under command of KNIL Lieutenant Colonel W.P. Roodenburg. On 19 February 1942 the Japanese forces landed near the town of Senoer [Senur]. The island was quickly captured.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Japanese occupation a Balinese military officer, <a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Gusti_Ngurah_Rai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Gusti Ngurah Rai (page does not exist)">Gusti Ngurah Rai</a>, formed a Balinese 'freedom army'. The lack of institutional changes from the time of Dutch rule however, and the harshness of war requisitions made Japanese rule worse than the Dutch one.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> Following Japan's Pacific surrender in August 1945, the Dutch promptly returned to Indonesia, including Bali, immediately to reinstate their pre-war colonial administration. This was resisted by the Balinese rebels now using Japanese weapons. On 20 November 1946, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Marga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Marga (page does not exist)">Battle of Marga</a> was fought in Tabanan in central Bali. Colonel I Gusti Ngurah Rai, by then 29 years old, finally rallied his forces in east Bali at Marga Rana, where they made a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Suicide_attack&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suicide attack (page does not exist)">suicide attack</a> on the heavily armed Dutch. The Balinese battalion was entirely wiped out, breaking the last thread of Balinese military resistance. In 1946 the Dutch constituted Bali as one of the 13 administrative districts of the newly proclaimed <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_of_East_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State of East Indonesia (page does not exist)">State of East Indonesia</a>, a rival state to the Republic of Indonesia which was proclaimed and headed by <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Hatta" title="Mohammad Hatta">Hatta</a>. Bali was included in the "Republic of the United States of Indonesia" when the Netherlands recognised Indonesian independence on 29 December 1949.
</p><p>The 1963 eruption of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Agung" title="Mount Agung">Mount Agung</a> killed thousands, created economic havoc and forced many displaced Balinese to be <i><a href="/wiki/Transmigration_program" title="Transmigration program">transmigrated</a></i> to other parts of Indonesia. Mirroring the widening of social divisions across Indonesia in the 1950s and early 1960s, Bali saw conflict between supporters of the traditional <a href="/wiki/Caste_system" title="Caste system" class="mw-redirect">caste system</a>, and those rejecting these traditional values. Politically, the opposition was represented by supporters of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Communist_Party&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Communist Party (page does not exist)">Indonesian Communist Party</a> (PKI) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Nationalist_Party&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Nationalist Party (page does not exist)">Indonesian Nationalist Party</a> (PNI), with tensions and ill-feeling further increased by the PKI's land reform programs.<sup id="cite_ref-ctpqur_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ctpqur-10">[10]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=30_September_Movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="30 September Movement (page does not exist)">An attempted coup</a> in Jakarta was put down by forces led by General Suharto. The army became the dominant power as it instigated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_killings_of_1965%E2%80%9366&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian killings of 1965–66 (page does not exist)">a violent anti-communist purge</a>, in which the army blamed the PKI for the coup. Most estimates suggest that at least 500,000 people were killed across Indonesia, with an estimated 80,000 killed in Bali, equivalent to 5% of the island's population.<sup id="cite_ref-ctpqur_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ctpqur-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Friend_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Friend-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ricklefs_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ricklefs-16">[16]</a></sup> With no Islamic forces involved as in Java and Sumatra, upper-caste PNI landlords led the extermination of PKI members.<sup id="cite_ref-Ricklefs_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ricklefs-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a result of the 1965/66 upheavals, Suharto was able to manoeuvre Sukarno <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transition_to_the_New_Order&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transition to the New Order (page does not exist)">out of the presidency</a>, and his <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Order_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Order (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">"New Order"</a> government reestablished relations with western countries. The pre-War Bali as "paradise" was revived in a modern form, and the resulting large growth in tourism has led to a dramatic increase in Balinese standards of living and significant foreign exchange earned for the country.<sup id="cite_ref-ctpqur_10-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ctpqur-10">[10]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/2002_Bali_bombings" title="2002 Bali bombings">A bombing in 2002</a> by militant <a href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist" class="mw-redirect">Islamists</a> in the tourist area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuta (page does not exist)">Kuta</a> killed 202 people, mostly foreigners. This attack, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2005_Bali_bombings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2005 Bali bombings (page does not exist)">another in 2005</a>, severely affected tourism, bringing much economic hardship to the island.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bali_Labeled.png" title="File:Bali Labeled.png">File:Bali Labeled.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Topography of the island</div></div></div>
<p>The island of Bali lies 3.2&#160;km (2&#160;mi) east of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Java_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Java (island) (page does not exist)">Java</a>, and is approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=8th_parallel_south&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="8th parallel south (page does not exist)">8 degrees south</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Equator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Equator (page does not exist)">equator</a>. Bali and Java are separated by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Strait&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Strait (page does not exist)">Bali Strait</a>. East to west, the island is approximately 153&#160;km (95&#160;mi) wide and spans approximately 112&#160;km (69&#160;mi) north to south; administratively it covers 5,780&#160;km<sup>2</sup>, or 5,577&#160;km<sup>2</sup> without <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Penida&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Penida (page does not exist)">Nusa Penida</a> District,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> its population density is roughly 750 people/km<sup>2</sup>.
</p><p>Bali's central mountains include several peaks over 3,000 metres in elevation. The highest is <a href="/wiki/Mount_Agung" title="Mount Agung">Mount Agung</a> (3,031 m), known as the "mother mountain" which is an active <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcano</a>. Mountains range from centre to the eastern side, with Mount Agung the easternmost peak. Bali's volcanic nature has contributed to its exceptional fertility and its tall mountain ranges provide the high rainfall that supports the highly productive agriculture sector. South of the mountains is a broad, steadily descending area where most of Bali's large rice crop is grown. The northern side of the mountains slopes more steeply to the sea and is the main coffee producing area of the island, along with rice, vegetables and cattle. The longest river, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ayung_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ayung River (page does not exist)">Ayung River</a>, flows approximately 75&#160;km.
</p><p>The island is surrounded by <a href="/wiki/Coral_reefs" title="Coral reefs" class="mw-redirect">coral reefs</a>. Beaches in the south tend to have white sand while those in the north and west have <a href="/wiki/Black_sand" title="Black sand">black sand</a>. Bali has no major waterways, although the Ho River is navigable by small <i><a href="/wiki/Sampan" title="Sampan">sampan</a></i> boats. Black sand beaches between Pasut and Klatingdukuh are being developed for tourism, but apart from the seaside temple of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tanah_Lot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tanah Lot (page does not exist)">Tanah Lot</a>, they are not yet used for significant tourism.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1_Tegalalang_rice_terrace_ubud_bali.jpg" title="File:1 Tegalalang rice terrace ubud bali.jpg">File:1 Tegalalang rice terrace ubud bali.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Subak_(irrigation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subak (irrigation) (page does not exist)">Subak</a> irrigation system</div></div></div>
<p>The largest city is the provincial capital, <a href="/wiki/Denpasar" title="Denpasar">Denpasar</a>, near the southern coast. Its population is around 491,500 (2002). Bali's second-largest city is the old colonial capital, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Singaraja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Singaraja (page does not exist)">Singaraja</a>, which is located on the north coast and is home to around 100,000 people. Other important cities include the beach resort, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuta (page does not exist)">Kuta</a>, which is practically part of Denpasar's urban area, and <a href="/wiki/Ubud" title="Ubud">Ubud</a>, situated at the north of Denpasar, is the island's cultural centre.
</p><p>Three small islands lie to the immediate south east and all are administratively part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Klungkung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Klungkung (page does not exist)">Klungkung</a> regency of Bali: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Penida&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Penida (page does not exist)">Nusa Penida</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Lembongan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Lembongan (page does not exist)">Nusa Lembongan</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Ceningan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Ceningan (page does not exist)">Nusa Ceningan</a>. These islands are separated from Bali by the Badung Strait.
</p><p>To the east, the <a href="/wiki/Lombok_Strait" title="Lombok Strait">Lombok Strait</a> separates Bali from <a href="/wiki/Lombok" title="Lombok">Lombok</a> and marks the <a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">biogeographical</a> division between the fauna of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indomalaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indomalaya (page does not exist)">Indomalayan</a> <a href="/wiki/Ecozone" title="Ecozone">ecozone</a> and the distinctly different fauna of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australasia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australasia (page does not exist)">Australasia</a>. The transition is known as the <a href="/wiki/Wallace_Line" title="Wallace Line">Wallace Line</a>, named after <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace" title="Alfred Russel Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a>, who first proposed a transition zone between these two major <a href="/wiki/Biome" title="Biome">biomes</a>. When sea levels dropped during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quaternary_glaciation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quaternary glaciation (page does not exist)">Pleistocene ice age</a>, Bali was connected to Java and <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a> and to the mainland of Asia and shared the Asian fauna, but the deep water of the Lombok Strait continued to keep Lombok Island and the <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Sunda_Islands" title="Lesser Sunda Islands">Lesser Sunda archipelago</a> isolated.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ecology">Ecology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refimprove_section&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refimprove section (page does not exist)">Template:Refimprove section</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bali_Mynah_-_Houston_Zoo.jpg" title="File:Bali Mynah - Houston Zoo.jpg">File:Bali Mynah - Houston Zoo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Starling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Starling (page does not exist)">Bali Starling</a> is found only on Bali and is critically endangered.</div></div></div>
<p>Bali lies just to the west of the <a href="/wiki/Wallace_Line" title="Wallace Line">Wallace Line</a>, and thus has a fauna that is Asian in character, with very little Australasian influence, and has more in common with Java than with Lombok.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}  An exception is the <a href="/wiki/Yellow-crested_Cockatoo" title="Yellow-crested Cockatoo">Yellow-crested Cockatoo</a>, a member of a primarily Australasian family. There are around 280 species of birds, including the critically endangered <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Starling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Starling (page does not exist)">Bali Starling</a>, which is <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a>. Others Include <a href="/wiki/Barn_Swallow" title="Barn Swallow">Barn Swallow</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black-naped_Oriole&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black-naped Oriole (page does not exist)">Black-naped Oriole</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_Racket-tailed_Treepie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black Racket-tailed Treepie (page does not exist)">Black Racket-tailed Treepie</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crested_Serpent-eagle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crested Serpent-eagle (page does not exist)">Crested Serpent-eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crested_Treeswift" title="Crested Treeswift">Crested Treeswift</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dollarbird" title="Dollarbird">Dollarbird</a>, <a href="/wiki/Java_Sparrow" title="Java Sparrow">Java Sparrow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Adjutant" title="Lesser Adjutant">Lesser Adjutant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Long-tailed_Shrike" title="Long-tailed Shrike">Long-tailed Shrike</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milky_Stork&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milky Stork (page does not exist)">Milky Stork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Swallow" title="Pacific Swallow">Pacific Swallow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red-rumped_Swallow" title="Red-rumped Swallow">Red-rumped Swallow</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sacred_Kingfisher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sacred Kingfisher (page does not exist)">Sacred Kingfisher</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sea_eagle_(bird)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sea eagle (bird) (page does not exist)">Sea Eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Woodswallow" title="Woodswallow">Woodswallow</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Savanna_Nightjar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Savanna Nightjar (page does not exist)">Savanna Nightjar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stork-billed_Kingfisher" title="Stork-billed Kingfisher">Stork-billed Kingfisher</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow-vented_Bulbul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow-vented Bulbul (page does not exist)">Yellow-vented Bulbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_Egret" title="Great Egret">White Heron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_Egret" title="Great Egret">Great Egret</a>.
</p><p>Until the early 20th century, Bali was home to several large mammals: the wild <a href="/wiki/Banteng" title="Banteng">Banteng</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">leopard</a> and the endemic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_tiger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali tiger (page does not exist)">Bali tiger</a>. The Banteng still occurs in its domestic form, whereas leopards are found only in neighbouring Java, and the Bali tiger is extinct. The last definite record of a tiger on Bali dates from 1937, when one was shot, though the subspecies may have survived until the 1940s or 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The relatively small size of the island, conflict with humans, poaching and habitat reduction drove the Bali tiger to extinction. This was the smallest and rarest of all tiger subspecies and was never caught on film or displayed in zoos, whereas few skins or bones remain in museums around the world. Today, the largest mammals are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Javan_Rusa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Javan Rusa (page does not exist)">Javan Rusa</a> deer and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wild_Boar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wild Boar (page does not exist)">Wild Boar</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}  A second, smaller species of deer, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Muntjac&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian Muntjac (page does not exist)">Indian Muntjac</a>, also occurs. <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_crocodile" title="Saltwater crocodile">Saltwater crocodiles</a> were once present on the island, but became locally extinct sometime during the last century.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Monkey_at_Ulu_Watu_Temple.jpg" title="File:Monkey at Ulu Watu Temple.jpg">File:Monkey at Ulu Watu Temple.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Monkey at Ulu Watu Temple</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Squirrel" title="Squirrel">Squirrels</a> are quite commonly encountered, less often is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_Palm_Civet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian Palm Civet (page does not exist)">Asian Palm Civet</a>, which is also kept in coffee farms to produce <a href="/wiki/Kopi_Luwak" title="Kopi Luwak">Kopi Luwak</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bat (page does not exist)">Bats</a> are well represented, perhaps the most famous place to encounter them remaining the Goa Lawah (Temple of the Bats) where they are worshipped by the locals and also constitute a tourist attraction. They also occur in other cave temples, for instance at Gangga Beach. Two species of <a href="/wiki/Old_World_monkey" title="Old World monkey">monkey</a> occur.  The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crab-eating_Macaque&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crab-eating Macaque (page does not exist)">Crab-eating Macaque</a>, known locally as "kera", is quite common around human settlements and temples, where it becomes accustomed to being fed by humans, particularly in any of the three "monkey forest" temples, such as the popular one in the <a href="/wiki/Ubud" title="Ubud">Ubud</a> area. They are also quite often kept as pets by locals. The second monkey, endemic to Java and some surrounding islands such as Bali, is far rarer and more elusive is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Javan_Langur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Javan Langur (page does not exist)">Javan Langur</a>, locally known as "lutung". They occur in few places apart from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Barat_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Barat National Park (page does not exist)">Bali Barat National Park</a>. They are born an orange colour, though by their first year they would have already changed to a more blackish colouration.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} In Java however, there is more of a tendency for this species to retain its juvenile orange colour into adulthood, and so you can see a mixture of black and orange monkeys together as a family. Other rarer mammals include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leopard_Cat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leopard Cat (page does not exist)">Leopard Cat</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunda_Pangolin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunda Pangolin (page does not exist)">Sunda Pangolin</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_Giant_Squirrel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black Giant Squirrel (page does not exist)">Black Giant Squirrel</a>.
</p><p>Snakes include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=King_Cobra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="King Cobra (page does not exist)">King Cobra</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reticulated_Python&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reticulated Python (page does not exist)">Reticulated Python</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Water_Monitor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Water Monitor (page does not exist)">Water Monitor</a> can grow to at least <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in length and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> and can move quickly.
</p><p>The rich coral reefs around the coast, particularly around popular diving spots such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tulamben&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tulamben (page does not exist)">Tulamben</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amed_(Bali)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amed (Bali) (page does not exist)">Amed</a>, Menjangan or neighbouring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Penida&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Penida (page does not exist)">Nusa Penida</a>, host a wide range of marine life, for instance <a href="/wiki/Hawksbill_Turtle" title="Hawksbill Turtle" class="mw-redirect">Hawksbill Turtle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mola_mola" title="Mola mola" class="mw-redirect">Giant Sunfish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manta_ray" title="Manta ray">Giant Manta Ray</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_moray&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant moray (page does not exist)">Giant Moray Eel</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bumphead_Parrotfish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bumphead Parrotfish (page does not exist)">Bumphead Parrotfish</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hammerhead_Shark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hammerhead Shark (page does not exist)">Hammerhead Shark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grey_reef_shark" title="Grey reef shark">Reef Shark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barracuda" title="Barracuda">barracuda</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sea_snake" title="Sea snake" class="mw-redirect">sea snakes</a>. Dolphins are commonly encountered on the north coast near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Singaraja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Singaraja (page does not exist)">Singaraja</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lovina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lovina (page does not exist)">Lovina</a>.
</p><p>A team of scientists conducted a survey from 29 April 2011 to 11 May 2011 at 33 sea sites around Bali. They discovered 952 species of reef fish of which 8 were new discoveries at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pemuteran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pemuteran (page does not exist)">Pemuteran</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gilimanuk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gilimanuk (page does not exist)">Gilimanuk</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Dua&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Dua (page does not exist)">Nusa Dua</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tulamben&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tulamben (page does not exist)">Tulamben</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Candidasa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Candidasa (page does not exist)">Candidasa</a>, and 393 coral species, including two new ones at <a href="/wiki/Padangbai" title="Padangbai">Padangbai</a> and between Padangbai and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amed_(Bali)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amed (Bali) (page does not exist)">Amed</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
The average coverage level of healthy coral was 36% (better than in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raja_Ampat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raja Ampat (page does not exist)">Raja Ampat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Halmahera" title="Halmahera">Halmahera</a> by 29% or in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fakfak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fakfak (page does not exist)">Fakfak</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kaimana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kaimana (page does not exist)">Kaimana</a> by 25%) with the highest coverage found in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gili_Selang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gili Selang (page does not exist)">Gili Selang</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gili_Mimpang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gili Mimpang (page does not exist)">Gili Mimpang</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Candidasa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Candidasa (page does not exist)">Candidasa</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Karangasem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Karangasem (page does not exist)">Karangasem</a> regency.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many plants have been introduced by humans within the last centuries, particularly since the 20th century, making it sometimes hard to distinguish what plants are really native.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Among the larger trees the most common are: <a href="/wiki/Banyan" title="Banyan">Banyan</a> trees, <a href="/wiki/Jackfruit" title="Jackfruit">Jackfruit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconuts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a> species, <a href="/wiki/Acacia" title="Acacia">acacia</a> trees and also endless rows of <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconuts</a> and banana species. Numerous flowers can be seen: <a href="/wiki/Hibiscus" title="Hibiscus">hibiscus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frangipani" title="Frangipani" class="mw-redirect">frangipani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bougainvillea" title="Bougainvillea">bougainvillea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poinsettia" title="Poinsettia">poinsettia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oleander&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oleander (page does not exist)">oleander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jasmine" title="Jasmine">jasmine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nymphaeaceae" title="Nymphaeaceae">water lily</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nelumbo" title="Nelumbo">lotus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rose" title="Rose">roses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Begonia" title="Begonia">begonias</a>, orchids and <a href="/wiki/Hydrangea" title="Hydrangea">hydrangeas</a> exist. On higher grounds that receive more moisture, for instance around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kintamani,_Bali&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kintamani, Bali (page does not exist)">Kintamani</a>, certain species of <a href="/wiki/Fern" title="Fern">fern</a> trees, <a href="/wiki/Mushroom" title="Mushroom">mushrooms</a> and even <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a> trees thrive well. Rice comes in many varieties. Other plants with agricultural value include: <a href="/wiki/Salak" title="Salak">salak</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mangosteen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mangosteen (page does not exist)">mangosteen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maize (page does not exist)">corn</a>, Kintamani orange, coffee and <a href="/wiki/Water_spinach" title="Water spinach" class="mw-redirect">water spinach</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h2>
<p>Some of the worst erosion has occurred in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lebih_Beach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lebih Beach (page does not exist)">Lebih Beach</a>, where up to 7 metres of land is lost every year. Decades ago, this beach was used for holy pilgrimages with more than 10,000 people, but they have now moved to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Masceti_Beach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Masceti Beach (page does not exist)">Masceti Beach</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>From ranked third in previous review, in 2010 Bali got score 99.65 of Indonesia's environmental quality index and the highest of all the 33 provinces. The score measured 3 water quality parameters: the level of <a href="/wiki/Total_suspended_solids" title="Total suspended solids">total suspended solids</a> (TSS), <a href="/wiki/Dissolved_oxygen" title="Dissolved oxygen" class="mw-redirect">dissolved oxygen</a> (DO) and <a href="/wiki/Chemical_oxygen_demand" title="Chemical oxygen demand">chemical oxygen demand</a> (COD).<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of over-exploitation by the tourist industry which converse massive land, 200 out of 400 rivers on the island have dried up and based on research, the southern part of Bali would face a water shortage up to 2,500 litres of clean water per second by 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
To ease the shortage, the central government plans to build a water catchment and processing facility at Petanu River in Gianyar. The 300 litres capacity of water per second will be channelled to Denpasar, Badung and Gianyar in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2>
<p>The province is divided into 8 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regencies_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regencies of Indonesia (page does not exist)">regencies</a> (<i>kabupaten</i>) and 1 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cities_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cities of Indonesia (page does not exist)">city</a> (<i>kota</i>). These are:
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-bottom: 0;">

<tr>
<th> Name </th>
<th> Capital </th>
<th> Area in <br /> km<sup>2</sup>. </th>

<th> Population <br /> 2010 Census

</td></tr>
