<td align="right"> 3,891,428
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p>Three decades ago, the Balinese economy was largely agriculture-based in terms of both output and employment. Tourism is now the largest single industry in terms of income, and as a result, Bali is one of Indonesia's wealthiest regions. About 80% of Bali's economy depends on tourism;<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Note: non-referenced&#160;% in the article: in fact a great number of the population still lives thanks to agriculture although this situation is changing rapidly.  By end of June 2011, <a href="/wiki/Non-performing_loan" title="Non-performing loan">non-performing loan</a> of all banks in Bali were 2.23%, lower than the average of Indonesian banking industry non-performing loan (about 5%).<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> The economy, however, suffered significantly as a result of the terrorist bombings <a href="/w/index.php?title=2002_Bali_bombing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2002 Bali bombing (page does not exist)">2002</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2005_Bali_bombing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2005 Bali bombing (page does not exist)">2005</a>. The tourism industry has since recovered from these events.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<p>Although tourism produces the GDP's largest output, agriculture is still the island's biggest employer;<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} most notably rice cultivation. Crops grown in smaller amounts include fruit, vegetables, <i><a href="/wiki/Coffea_arabica" title="Coffea arabica">Coffea arabica</a></i> and other <a href="/wiki/Cash_crop" title="Cash crop">cash</a> and subsistence crops.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Fishing also provides a significant number of jobs. Bali is also famous for its <a href="/wiki/Artisan" title="Artisan">artisans</a> who produce a vast array of handicrafts, including <a href="/wiki/Batik" title="Batik">batik</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ikat" title="Ikat">ikat</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Nusra_Tangi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Nusra Tangi (page does not exist)">cloth and clothing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Woodworking" title="Woodworking">wooden carvings</a>, stone carvings, painted art and silverware. Notably, individual villages typically adopt a single product, such as wind chimes or wooden furniture.
</p><p>The Arabica coffee production region is the highland region of Kintamani near <a href="/wiki/Mount_Batur" title="Mount Batur">Mount Batur</a>. Generally, Balinese coffee is processed using the wet method. This results in a sweet, soft coffee with good consistency. Typical flavours include lemon and other citrus notes.<sup id="cite_ref-SCAI_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCAI-29">[29]</a></sup> Many coffee farmers in Kintamani are members of a traditional farming system called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subak_(irrigation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subak (irrigation) (page does not exist)">Subak Abian</a>, which is based on the <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> philosophy of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tri_Hita_Karana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tri Hita Karana (page does not exist)">Tri Hita Karana</a>". According to this philosophy, the three causes of happiness are good relations with God, other people and the environment. The Subak Abian system is ideally suited to the production of fair trade and organic coffee production. Arabica coffee from Kintamani is the first product in Indonesia to request a <a href="/wiki/Geographical_Indication" title="Geographical Indication" class="mw-redirect">Geographical Indication</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BaliKintamani_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BaliKintamani-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bali_canyoning.jpg" title="File:Bali canyoning.jpg">File:Bali canyoning.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Canyoning in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gitgit_Waterfall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gitgit Waterfall (page does not exist)">Gitgit Waterfall</a>, Bali, Indonesia</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1_tirtha_empul_temple.jpg" title="File:1 tirtha empul temple.jpg">File:1 tirtha empul temple.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tirtha_Empul_Temple&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tirtha Empul Temple (page does not exist)">Tirtha Empul Temple</a> draws tourists who seek its holy waters</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1_pura_taman_ayun_bali_2011.jpg" title="File:1 pura taman ayun bali 2011.jpg">File:1 pura taman ayun bali 2011.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pura Taman Ayun, another temple which is a popular tourist destination</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refimprove_section&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refimprove section (page does not exist)">Template:Refimprove section</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arjuna_statue.JPG" title="File:Arjuna statue.JPG">File:Arjuna statue.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A statue of Arjuna on a street in Bali</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Tourism_industry" title="Tourism industry" class="mw-redirect">tourism industry</a> is primarily focused in the south, while significant in the other parts of the island as well. The main tourist locations are the town of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuta (page does not exist)">Kuta</a> (with its beach), and its outer suburbs of Legian and <a href="/wiki/Seminyak" title="Seminyak">Seminyak</a> (which were once independent townships), the east coast town of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sanur_(Bali)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sanur (Bali) (page does not exist)">Sanur</a> (once the only tourist hub), in the center of the island <a href="/wiki/Ubud" title="Ubud">Ubud</a>, to the south of the <a href="/wiki/Ngurah_Rai_International_Airport" title="Ngurah Rai International Airport">Ngurah Rai International Airport</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jimbaran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jimbaran (page does not exist)">Jimbaran</a>, and the newer development of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nusa_Dua&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nusa Dua (page does not exist)">Nusa Dua</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pecatu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pecatu (page does not exist)">Pecatu</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/American_government" title="American government" class="mw-redirect">American government</a> lifted its travel warnings in 2008. The Australian government last issued an advice on Friday, 4 May 2012. The overall level of the advice was lowered to 'Exercise a high degree of caution'. The Swedish government issued a new warning on Sunday, 10 June 2012 because of one more tourist who has been killed by methanol poisoning.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kuta_Beach.JPG" title="File:Kuta Beach.JPG">File:Kuta Beach.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Kuta Beach is a popular tourist spot in Bali</div></div></div>An offshoot of tourism is the growing real estate industry. Bali real estate has been rapidly developing in the main tourist areas of Kuta, Legian, Seminyak and Oberoi. Most recently, high-end 5 star projects are under development on the Bukit peninsula, on the south side of the island. Million dollar villas are being developed along the cliff sides of south Bali, commanding panoramic ocean views. Foreign and domestic (many Jakarta individuals and companies are fairly active) investment into other areas of the island also continues to grow. Land prices, despite the worldwide economic crisis, have remained stable.
<p>In the last half of 2008, Indonesia's currency had dropped approximately 30% against the US dollar, providing many overseas visitors value for their currencies. Visitor arrivals for 2009 were forecast to drop 8% (which would be higher than 2007 levels), due to the worldwide economic crisis which has also affected the global tourist industry, but not due to any travel warnings.
</p><p>Bali's tourism economy survived the terrorist bombings of 2002 and 2005, and the tourism industry has in fact slowly recovered and surpassed its pre-terrorist bombing levels; the longterm trend has been a steady increase of visitor arrivals. In 2010, Bali received 2.57 million foreign tourists, which surpassed the target of 2.0–2.3 million tourists. The average occupancy of starred hotels achieved 65%, so the island is still able to accommodate tourists for some years without any addition of new rooms/hotels,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> although at the peak season some of them are fully booked.
</p><p>Bali received the Best Island award from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Travel_and_Leisure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Travel and Leisure (page does not exist)">Travel and Leisure</a> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> The island of Bali won because of its attractive surroundings (both mountain and coastal areas), diverse tourist attractions, excellent international and local restaurants, and the friendliness of the local people. According to BBC Travel released in 2011, Bali is one of the World's Best Islands, rank in second after <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2010, the film version of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eat,_Pray,_Love&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eat, Pray, Love (page does not exist)">Eat, Pray, Love</a> (EPL) was released in theatres. The movie was based on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_Gilbert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth Gilbert (page does not exist)">Elizabeth Gilbert</a>'s best-selling memoir of the same name. It took place at Ubud and Padang-Padang Beach at Bali. The 2006 book, which spent 57 weeks at the No. 1 spot on the New York Times paperback nonfiction best-seller list, had already fuelled a boom in EPL tourism in Ubud, the hill town and cultural and tourist center that was the focus of Gilbert's quest for balance through traditional spirituality and healing that leads to love.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2011, China has displaced Japan as the second-largest supplier of tourists to Bali, while Australia still tops the list. Chinese tourists increased by 17% from last year due to the impact of <a href="/w/index.php?title=ACFTA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ACFTA (page does not exist)">ACFTA</a> and new direct flights to Bali.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
In January 2012, Chinese tourists year on year (yoy) increased by 222.18% compared to January 2011, while Japanese tourists declined by 23.54% yoy.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bali reported that it has 2.88 million foreign tourists and 5 million domestic tourists in 2012, marginally surpassing the expectations of 2.8 million foreign tourists. Forecasts for 2013 are at 3.1 million.<sup id="cite_ref-balitourism_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-balitourism-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Based on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bank Indonesia (page does not exist)">Bank Indonesia</a> survey in May 2013, 34.39 percent of tourists are upper-middle class with spending between $1,286 to $5,592 and dominated by Australia, France, China, Germany and the US with some China tourists move from low spending before to higher spending currently. While 30.26 percent are middle class with spending between $662 to $1,285.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Update |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bali_moped_col.jpg" title="File:Bali moped col.jpg">File:Bali moped col.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A major form of transport in Bali is the <a href="/wiki/Moped" title="Moped">Moped</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ngurah_Rai_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ngurah Rai Airport (page does not exist)">Ngurah Rai International Airport</a> is located near Jimbaran, on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isthmus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isthmus (page does not exist)">isthmus</a> at the southernmost part of the island. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lt.Col._Wisnu_Airfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lt.Col. Wisnu Airfield (page does not exist)">Lt.Col. Wisnu Airfield</a> is found in north-west Bali.
</p><p>A coastal road circles the island, and three major two-lane arteries cross the central mountains at passes reaching to 1,750m in height (at Penelokan). The Ngurah Rai Bypass is a four-lane expressway that partly encircles Denpasar and enables cars to travel quickly in the heavily populated south. Bali has no railway lines yet.
</p><p>December 2010: Government of Indonesia has invited investors to build Tanah Ampo Cruise Terminal at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Karangasem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Karangasem (page does not exist)">Karangasem</a>, Bali amounted $30&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> In 17 July 2011 the first cruise ship (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sun_Princess&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sun Princess (page does not exist)">Sun Princess</a>) will anchor about 400 meters away from the wharf of Tanah Ampo harbour. The current pier is only 154 meters and will eventually be 300 to 350 meters to accommodate international cruise ships. The harbour would be safer than Benoa and has a scenic backdrop of a panoramic view of mountainous area with green rice fields.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> By December 2011 the auction process will be settled and Tanah Ampo is predicted to become the main hub for cruise ships in Indonesia by 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>A Memorandum of Understanding has been signed by two ministers, Bali's Governor and <a href="/w/index.php?title=PT_Kereta_Api&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PT Kereta Api (page does not exist)">Indonesian Train Company</a> to build 565 kilometres of railway along the coast around the island. It should be operating by 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 16 March 2011 (Tanjung) Benoa port received the "Best Port Welcome 2010" award from London's "Dream World Cruise Destination" magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Government plans to expand the role of Benoa port as export-import port to boost Bali's trade and industry sector.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> The Tourism and Creative Economy Ministry has confirmed that 306 cruise liners are heading for Indonesia in 2013 – an increase of 43 percent compared to the previous year.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 2011, an integrated Areal Traffic Control System (ATCS) was implemented to reduce traffic jams at four crossing points: Ngurah Rai statue, Dewa Ruci Kuta crossing, Jimbaran crossing and Sanur crossing. ATCS is an integrated system connecting all traffic lights, CCTVs and other traffic signals with a monitoring office at the police headquarters. It has successfully been implemented in other ASEAN countries and will be implemented at other crossings in Bali.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 21 December 2011 construction started on the Nusa Dua-Benoa-<a href="/wiki/Ngurah_Rai_International_Airport" title="Ngurah Rai International Airport">Ngurah Rai International Airport</a> toll road which will also provide a special lane for motorcycles. This has been done by seven state-owned enterprises led by PT Jasa Marga with 60% of shares. PT Jasa Marga Bali Tol will construct the 9.91 kilometres toll road (totally 12.7 kilometres with access road). The construction is estimated to cost Rp.2.49 trillion ($273.9 million). The project goes through 2 kilometres of mangrove forest and through 2.3 kilometres of beach, both within 5.4 hectares area. The elevated toll road is built over the mangrove forest on 18,000 concrete pillars which occupied 2 hectares of mangroves forest. It compensated by new planting of 300,000 mangrove trees along the road. On 21 December 2011 the Dewa Ruci 450 meters underpass has also started on the busy Dewa Ruci junction near Bali Kuta Galeria with an estimated cost of Rp136 billion ($14.9 million) from the state budget.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> On 23 September 2013, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Mandara_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Mandara Toll Road (page does not exist)">Bali Mandara Toll Road</a> is opened and the Dewa Ruci Junction (Simpang Siur) underpass is opened before. Both are ease the heavy traffic congestion.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>To solve chronic traffic problems, the province will also build a toll road connecting Serangan with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tohpati&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tohpati (page does not exist)">Tohpati</a>, a toll road connecting Kuta, Denpasar and Tohpati and a flyover connecting Kuta and Ngurah Rai Airport.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Historical_populations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Historical populations (page does not exist)">Template:Historical populations</a>
The population of Bali was 3,890,757 as of the 2010 Census. There are an estimated 30,000 expatriates living in Bali.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_origins">Ethnic origins</span></h3>
<p>A DNA study in 2005 by Karafet et al.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> found that 12% of Balinese <a href="/wiki/Y-chromosome" title="Y-chromosome" class="mw-redirect">Y-chromosomes</a> are of likely Indian origin, while 84% are of likely <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austronesian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austronesian (page does not exist)">Austronesian</a> origin, and 2% of likely <a href="/wiki/Melanesian" title="Melanesian" class="mw-redirect">Melanesian</a> origin. The study does not correlate the DNA samples to the Balinese caste system.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Caste_system">Caste system</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Bali has a caste system based on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_caste_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian caste system (page does not exist)">Indian Hindu model</a>, with four castes:
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shudra" title="Shudra">Shudras</a> – <a href="/wiki/Peasant" title="Peasant">peasants</a> constituting close to 93% of Bali's population.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Wesias (<a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishyas</a>) – the caste of merchants and administrative officials
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_Kshatriya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese Kshatriya (page does not exist)">Ksatrias</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kshatriya" title="Kshatriya">Kshatriyas</a>) – the kingly and <a href="/wiki/Warrior" title="Warrior">warrior</a> caste
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmins</a> – holy men and priests
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Bar_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Bar box (page does not exist)">Template:Bar box</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mother_Temple_of_Besakih.jpg" title="File:Mother Temple of Besakih.jpg">File:Mother Temple of Besakih.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mother_Temple_of_Besakih&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mother Temple of Besakih (page does not exist)">Mother Temple of Besakih</a>, one of Bali's most significant <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> temples.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ubud_Cremation_Procession_1.jpg" title="File:Ubud Cremation Procession 1.jpg">File:Ubud Cremation Procession 1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A religious procession</div></div></div>
<p>Unlike most of Muslim-majority Indonesia, about 83.5% of Bali's population adheres to <a href="/wiki/Balinese_Hinduism" title="Balinese Hinduism">Balinese Hinduism</a>, formed as a combination of existing <a href="/wiki/Balinese_mythology" title="Balinese mythology">local beliefs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> influences from mainland Southeast Asia and South Asia. Minority religions include Islam (13.3%), Christianity (1.7%), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a> (0.5%).<sup id="cite_ref-census2010_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2010-3">[3]</a></sup> These figures do not include immigrants from other parts of Indonesia.
</p><p>When Islam surpassed <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> in <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a> (16th century), Bali became a refuge for many Hindus. Balinese Hinduism is an amalgam in which gods and demigods are worshipped together with Buddhist heroes, the spirits of ancestors, indigenous agricultural deities and sacred places. Religion as it is practised in Bali is a composite belief system that embraces not only theology, philosophy, and mythology, but ancestor worship, animism and magic. It pervades nearly every aspect of traditional life. <a href="/wiki/Caste" title="Caste">Caste</a> is observed, though less strictly than in India. With an estimated 20,000 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pura_(Balinese_temple)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pura (Balinese temple) (page does not exist)">puras (temples)</a> and shrines, Bali is known as the "Island of a Thousand Puras", or "Island of the Gods".<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Balinese Hinduism has roots in Indian Hinduism and in Buddhism, and adopted the animistic traditions of the indigenous people. This influence strengthened the belief that the gods and goddesses are present in all things. Every element of nature, therefore, possesses its own power, which reflects the power of the gods. A rock, tree, dagger, or woven cloth is a potential home for spirits whose energy can be directed for good or evil. Balinese Hinduism is deeply interwoven with art and ritual. Ritualizing states of self-control are a notable feature of religious expression among the people, who for this reason have become famous for their graceful and decorous behaviour.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from the majority of Balinese Hindus, there also exist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_Indonesian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese Indonesian (page does not exist)">Chinese</a> immigrants whose traditions have melded with that of the locals. As a result, these Sino-Balinese not only embrace their original religion, which is a mixture of Buddhism, Christianity, Taoism and Confucianism, but also find a way to harmonise it with the local traditions. Hence, it is not uncommon to find local Sino-Balinese during the local temple's <i>odalan</i>. Moreover, Balinese Hindu priests are invited to perform rites alongside a Chinese priest in the event of the death of a Sino-Balinese.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the Sino-Balinese claim to embrace Buddhism for administrative purposes, such as their Identity Cards.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Balinese_language" title="Balinese language">Balinese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_language" title="Indonesian language">Indonesian</a> are the most widely spoken languages in Bali, and the vast majority of <a href="/wiki/Balinese_people" title="Balinese people">Balinese people</a> are <a href="/wiki/Bilingual" title="Bilingual" class="mw-redirect">bilingual</a> or <a href="/wiki/Trilingual" title="Trilingual" class="mw-redirect">trilingual</a>. The most common spoken language around the tourist areas is Indonesian, as many people in the tourist sector are not solely Balinese, but migrants from Java, Lombok, Sumatra, and other parts of Indonesia. There are several indigenous Balinese languages, but most Balinese can also use the most widely spoken option: modern common Balinese. The usage of different Balinese languages was traditionally determined by the <a href="/wiki/Balinese_caste_system" title="Balinese caste system">Balinese caste system</a> and by clan membership, but this tradition is diminishing. <a href="/wiki/Kawi_language" title="Kawi language">Kawi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> are also commonly used by some Hindu priests in Bali, for Hinduism literature was mostly written in Sanskrit.
</p><p>English is a common third language (and the primary foreign language) of many Balinese, owing to the requirements of the <a href="/wiki/Tourism_industry" title="Tourism industry" class="mw-redirect">tourism industry</a>. Other foreign languages, such as Chinese, Japanese, <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>, French or German are often used in multilingual signs for foreign tourists.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kecak.JPG" title="File:Kecak.JPG">File:Kecak.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A Kecak dance being performed at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Uluwatu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uluwatu (page does not exist)">Uluwatu</a>, in Bali</div></div></div>
<p>Bali is renowned for its diverse and sophisticated art forms, such as painting, sculpture, woodcarving, handcrafts, and performing arts. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese cuisine (page does not exist)">Balinese cuisine</a> is also distinctive. Balinese percussion orchestra music, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Gamelan" title="Gamelan">gamelan</a></i>, is highly developed and varied. Balinese performing arts often portray stories from Hindu epics such as the <a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a> but with heavy Balinese influence. Famous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_dance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese dance (page does not exist)">Balinese dances</a> include <i><a href="/wiki/Pendet" title="Pendet">pendet</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Legong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legong (page does not exist)">legong</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Baris_(dance)" title="Baris (dance)">baris</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Topeng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Topeng (page does not exist)">topeng</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Barong_(mythology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barong (mythology) (page does not exist)">barong</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Gamelan_gong_kebyar" title="Gamelan gong kebyar">gong keybar</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Kecak" title="Kecak">kecak</a></i> (the monkey dance). Bali boasts one of the most diverse and innovative performing arts cultures in the world, with paid performances at thousands of temple festivals, private ceremonies, or public shows.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hindu New Year, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nyepi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nyepi (page does not exist)">Nyepi</a></i>, is celebrated in the spring by a day of silence. On this day everyone stays at home and tourists are encouraged to remain in their hotels. On the day before New Year, large and colourful sculptures of <i>ogoh-ogoh</i> monsters are paraded and finally burned in the evening to drive away evil spirits. Other festivals throughout the year are specified by the Balinese <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pawukon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pawukon (page does not exist)">pawukon</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Calendar" title="Calendar">calendrical</a> system.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ubud_Cremation_4.jpg" title="File:Ubud Cremation 4.jpg">File:Ubud Cremation 4.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Cremation" title="Cremation">Cremation</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ubud" title="Ubud">Ubud</a></div></div></div>
<p>Celebrations are held for many occasions such as a tooth-filing (coming-of-age ritual), <a href="/wiki/Cremation" title="Cremation">cremation</a> or <i>odalan</i> (temple festival). One of the most important concepts that Balinese ceremonies have in common is that of <i>désa kala patra</i>, which refers to how ritual performances must be appropriate in both the specific and general social context.<sup id="cite_ref-Herbst_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Herbst-62">[62]</a></sup> Many of the ceremonial art forms such as <i><a href="/wiki/Wayang" title="Wayang">wayang kulit</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Topeng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Topeng (page does not exist)">topeng</a></i> are highly improvisatory, providing flexibility for the performer to adapt the performance to the current situation.<sup id="cite_ref-Foley_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foley-63">[63]</a></sup> Many celebrations call for a loud, boisterous atmosphere with lots of activity and the resulting aesthetic, <i>ramé</i>, is distinctively Balinese. Often two or more <i><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Bali" title="Music of Bali">gamelan</a></i> ensembles will be performing well within earshot, and sometimes compete with each other to be heard. Likewise, the audience members talk amongst themselves, get up and walk around, or even cheer on the performance, which adds to the many layers of activity and the liveliness typical of <i>ramé</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Kaja</i> and <i>kelod</i> are the Balinese equivalents of North and South, which refer to ones orientation between the island's largest mountain Gunung Agung (<i>kaja</i>), and the sea (<i>kelod</i>). In addition to spatial orientation, <i>kaja</i> and <i>kelod</i> have the connotation of good and evil; gods and ancestors are believed to live on the mountain whereas demons live in the sea. Buildings such as temples and residential homes are spatially oriented by having the most sacred spaces closest to the mountain and the unclean places nearest to the sea.<sup id="cite_ref-Herbst_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Herbst-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most temples have an inner courtyard and an outer courtyard which are arranged with the inner courtyard furthest <i>kaja</i>. These spaces serve as performance venues since most Balinese rituals are accompanied by any combination of music, dance and drama. The performances that take place in the inner courtyard are classified as <i>wali</i>, the most sacred rituals which are offerings exclusively for the gods, while the outer courtyard is where <i>bebali</i> ceremonies are held, which are intended for gods and people. Lastly, performances meant solely for the entertainment of humans take place outside the walls of the temple and are called <i>bali-balihan</i>. This three-tiered system of classification was standardised in 1971 by a committee of Balinese officials and artists to better protect the sanctity of the oldest and most sacred Balinese rituals from being performed for a paying audience.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tourism, Bali's chief industry, has provided the island with a foreign audience that is eager to pay for entertainment, thus creating new performance opportunities and more demand for performers. The impact of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tourism_in_indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tourism in indonesia (page does not exist)">tourism</a> is controversial since before it became integrated into the economy, the Balinese performing arts did not exist as a capitalist venture, and were not performed for entertainment outside of their respective ritual context. Since the 1930s sacred rituals such as the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Barong_(mythology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barong (mythology) (page does not exist)">barong</a></i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_dance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese dance (page does not exist)">dance</a> have been performed both in their original contexts, as well as exclusively for paying tourists. This has led to new versions of many of these performances which have developed according to the preferences of foreign audiences; some villages have a <i>barong</i> mask specifically for non-ritual performances as well as an older mask which is only used for sacred performances.<sup id="cite_ref-Sanger_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sanger-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Balinese society continues to revolve around each family's ancestral village, to which the cycle of life and religion is closely tied.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-68">[68]</a></sup> Coercive aspects of traditional society, such as <a href="/wiki/Customary_law" title="Customary law" class="mw-redirect">customary law</a> sanctions imposed by traditional authorities such as village councils (including "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Kasepekang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kasepekang (page does not exist)">kasepekang</a>", or <a href="/wiki/Shunning" title="Shunning">shunning</a>) have risen in importance as a consequence of the democratisation and decentralisation of Indonesia since 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Gallery">Gallery</span></h2>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM De beroemde Balinese danser I Mario TMnr 10004713.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The famous dancer I Mario, picture taken 1940.
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Portert van twee jonge Balinese danseressen TMnr 10004678b.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Balinese_dance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balinese dance (page does not exist)">Balinese dancers</a> wearing elaborate headgear, photographed in 1929. Digitally restored.
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Balinese Stone Carvings.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Stone carvings in Ubud.
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Balinese stone guardian.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Balinese stone guardian at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ubud_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ubud Palace (page does not exist)">Ubud Palace</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2>
<p>Bali was the host of <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Asian_Beach_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Asian Beach Games (page does not exist)">2008 Asian Beach Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> It was the second time Indonesia hosted an Asia-level <a href="/wiki/Multi-sport_event" title="Multi-sport event">multi-sport event</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a> held the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1962_Asian_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1962 Asian Games (page does not exist)">1962 Asian Games</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Heritage_sites">Heritage sites</span></h2>
<p>On June 2012, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subak_(irrigation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subak (irrigation) (page does not exist)">Subak</a>, the irrigation system for <a href="/wiki/Paddy_field" title="Paddy field">paddy fields</a> in Bali was enlisted as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO_world_heritage_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO world heritage site (page does not exist)">UNESCO world heritage site</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Beauty_Pageant">Beauty Pageant</span></h2>
<p>Bali was the host of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Miss_World_2013&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Miss World 2013 (page does not exist)">Miss World 2013</a>, It was the first time Indonesia hosted an International Beauty Pageant
</p>

</li>
</ul>
